gBhRpd-8aYSbW_dGLd4myQ.text: I was looking for something different and started searching restaurants in London and came across The Gay Hussar, a Hungarian restaurant in SOHO.  I arrived at 5:30pm to take advantage of their pre-theatre offer of 20 percent off all food until 6:30pm.  There were one couple awaiting at the door which opened promptly at 5:30pm and the place became almost filled by 6:45pm.  The delicious bread basket and a dish of peppers arrived with the menu.  I ordered a glass of the house Hungarian red wine which was very good.  I decided on the venison goulash with red cabbage and tarhonya (Hungarian noodles; a plentiful delicious meal.  Then I ordered the poppyseed strudel topped with ice cream.  The busy manager and his staff provide excellent service and they indicate their appreciation when leaving - it's nice to get a warm welcome and good service.  The prices are very reasonable and the 20 percent discount is a real plus.  Check out the menus on their web site and they do take reservations.  I am looking forward to my next meal at The Gay Hussar on my next trio to London.

F-fH5zwAXhiSF-1BM92c7A.text: Fantastic place. Can look a little intimidating from the outside, especially if you are not an age old Londoner or politician but what a gem on the inside. The staff will make you feel nothing but completely welcome and the interiors are very unique and it is cosy and intimate. The food is hearty and very traditionally Hungarian. I would recommend a) being hungary b) Hungarian wine c) the duck.

6_VghO9PWh-JDy4mb-TmEA.text: I do not really know anything about Hungarian food, so I will not comment if this place is authentic or not. I wanted to go there two or three times, but they were always fully booked. Finally I managed to get a table when I walked in recently. The Gay Hussar looks a bit old fashioned and its walls are plastered with drawings of people who supposedly dined there. I liked the images and thought it's an original feature and more interesting than random paintings or white walls. The first disappointment came with the wine menu. While the menu looks fine, I was not happy that they offer only the unspecified house wine by the glass. I really do not like when places only offer one random wine by the glass. Anyway, the house white was alright, so it was not too bad. I started my dinner with the delicious brown bread with butter. At many restaurants you get somewhat bland white bread. Not here. At The Guy Hussar I enjoyed very tasty brown bread with a bit of butter, definitely one of the better breads you can get in London. Then I continued with Debreceni Kolbász, basically a spicy Hungarian sausage. As I went there in my discovery of the best Wiener schnitzel in London, I ordered "Bécsi Szelet", the veal escalope with potates. First, there are not many places in London that have veal escalope on the menu. And second, this was definitely one of the best Wiener schnitzels I had in London so far. The bread crumbs were light brown and in contrast to many other places, the crust was what I would call fluffy. Really nice and tasty and just like a good escalope should be. The only criticism is that the large escalope with tasty sliced and roasted potatoes was a bit try. I should really have asked for some gravy to go with it.For dessert I decided to order the "Dobos Torta", a "layered gateau with caramel top" that tasted very good. The Gay Hussar is a busy place and it can be difficult to get a table without a booking. It might not cater all tastes, but no question, if you like a good veal escalope, this is a place for you.

yKD9u9PE0Jk4VA3jIPw5tQ.text: Ate here when we were on vacay, and loved it. The food was fantastic - literally the best hummus I've ever had - and the staff was very attentive. If you are visiting or live near here, you should give it a shot.

ZHgWbRTyK3Izmel77_m9ZQ.text: My family have been there since the 60s when they came over from Hungary. Good traditional Hungarian food, heavy, warming, rich, tasty. Def one for a winter meal rather than a light bite. If you've written a book take it with you and they'll add it to their shelves...

R1dK3EK258Mk9Swn0u8YVQ.text: Had a spectacular night out with my family at this cozy little Hungarian restaurant! My veal goulash was superb (Although personally I prefer slightly more spice, however my father ordered the same and found his to be the perfect amount for him), and the service was very friendly as well. The raspberry sorbet for dessert was divine. It had just the right amount of sweetness without being overpowering. Overall, it is definitely worthy of 5 stars in my book.

PxFi7aGnJ07ViQ7hCkLCwQ.text: Very nice overall. The food was quite good and the goulash was great. Just don't make the mistake we made and that is eat the chili pepper on the table. Boy was that hot. The place is small and filled up pretty quickly on Friday night. A very nice wine selection but not much on the beer selection.

7kRWonDWRKX_MtA8n3IOZQ.text: This is one of those places you've heard about for many years, but somehow never really got round to sampling.Well, today I corrected that oversight, and frankly was underwhelmed.The food was average, the wine list over-priced, the service mediocre.So a middle of the road rating is all I can justify - the place simply hasn't got enough going for it to justify a repeat visit in my opinion in a World City like London with so many other options.

QtkfbsvERA0fH7pKhFIo7w.text: Very nice food, good service and there is always at least one person who actually speaks Hungarian language as well, portions are sizeable and it has a really "home" atmosphere. Venison gulags is my favourite.

7tFtsXLTMJNFNWf1JxFGzA.text: A popular hangout with journalists, artists, writers, and politicians (whose framed caricatures and photos cover the walls), this is one of our favorite restaurants in London and one of the best anywhere we have traveled.Their 3-course pre-theatre menu, served Monday to Saturday from 5.30 - 6.30pm and Saturday from 12.30 - 2.00pm, is a real bargain at  £17.00. Best of all the starter options include their famous chilled wild cherry soup, a delectable combination of sweet fruit and tangy lemon juice.  The Transylvanian stuffed cabbage is served with sauerkraut and grilled smoked bacon and sausage, and the  cheese pancakes are a nice choice for dessert, which includes tea or coffee. Ordered a la carte these selections would total £23.50.The regular menu offers such specialties as roast duck, venison goulash, and  veal wiener schnitzel.Tables are very close to each other and the dining room can get noisy at peak dining times. Service always has been impeccable. I cannot recommend the Gay Hussar highly enough.

photos.caption: Photo of Gay Hussar - London, United Kingdom. Ground floor dining room

mUP2Ipqepah3R_hNne83Vw.text: We had a great meal here.  The food was very authentic Hungarian items (there were a few items on the menu more Hungarian-style than authentic) but otherwise very impressed with the food and service.  We would definitely return next time in London.

c5u1JqbG0QBXkig8vL_HcQ.text: This famed London landmark remains delicious and welcoming. Dinner and drinks were wonderful, a charming evening.

-VEYOpyzyCkOsHRKRPycZg.text: If ever you were to try and find a gay hussar in London I reckon Greek Street in Soho would be as apt a place as any to start looking! Luckily for us Londoners, this glad Hungarian eatery has been serving excellent continental cuisine for more than 50 years in one of London's most atmospheric and authentic central European restaurants. There are many reasons to love the Gay Hussar. It's the sort of place where aged gentlemen donning tweet jackets and speaking with marbles in the mouth upper crust accents go to discuss terribly important matters over terribly delicious lunches. It's also a restaurant renowned for its favoured status among politicos (as a wall full of caricatures of notable politicians who've dined here attests). Indeed, rumour has it Tom Blair was persuaded to run for PM right here in this den-like Soho institution. You certainly can't blame such big wigs for frequenting this restaurant. With its the cushy benches, wood panelling and invitingly delectable old world aromas wafting out from the kitchen, the Gay Hussar is as cosy as they come (the private dining rooms on the first and second floors ensure discretion too). Of course, the Hussar's real draw is the food  and especially the goulash! Yes, the Gay Hussar's veal goulash with galuska (satisfyingly clumpy little doughy dumplings) is a treat. Best saved for dreary winter dining but devour-able all year round, this savoury and paprika-rich dish is probably the most warming meal to be had in the whole West End. Consider visiting at lunch when £18.50 buys two courses and £21.50 allows for a third. I heartily recommend the fried mushrooms with tartar sauce as a starter and have no complaints about the poppyseed strudel with vanilla ice cream for puds. There's a wonderful 'best of Hungary' wine list for connoisseurs as well. A perfect venue for the festive season or any occasion requiring an intimate setting for supper, the Gay Hussar sets a remarkable tone. As for this restaurant's name, well, when it opened the word gay didn't have the connotations it does today and was simply meant to describe the fiery and exuberant nature of Hungarian calvarymen, whom Gay Hussar founder Victor Sassie held in the highest regard after serving in Budapest during the Second World War. A comfortable and historic setting with the best goulash in London  splendid doesn't begin to describe this marvellous restaurant.

c7zEugmiMs5APvDwHnkJig.text: My fiance said this was the most comfortable restaurant she'd ever eaten in.  I have to agree.  It's very low key.  I almost bit my finger off because they don't give you forks.  I ordered the goulash soup, and a midget wearing a fruit basket on his head, and long johns came out screaming "who ordered the soup??".  I didn't say anything, because I was completely shocked.  So he starts shouting "I know that goddamned soup dint order itself!"  I raised my hand and said rather meekily "Uhm, I ordered the goulash soup."  Then he goes "Oh, well it's about time I get a god damned answer around here!"  At this point he and the maitre d' give each other a knowing glance, and a nod.  Then, they grabbed me!No, none of that happened, but it's an excellent place to eat, and they do give you forks.  Many forks in fact.  Maybe tooooo many.  Get the Egri Bikaver.  Damn fine bottle of wine.  Also, the venison goulash should not be missed.  I wouldn't overlook the duck either.  A broad across from us ordered it.  It was all I could do not to snatch it up, run out onto the street, and down an alley to devour it in the chilly london night.  Mugsy?  Mugsy is that you in the darkness??  Mugsy are you growling?  Mugsy come out it's not funny anymore!  Mugsy help there's someone in our spot!  Some one...some....thing....mugs, mugs....*heavy breath and growling*  Silence.Tune in next time for the thrilling conclusion of "Haunted Goulash:  Tales of the Gay Hussar(prounounce Huzz-are)

VdVn0L-7A5wxuTi_97ZFGw.text: It is the traditional Hungarian meals and taste! Really thematic! Reminds me of mi childhood! Recommended!

Fk7GzyptswHmZNXdjG4Qxw.text: As you enter this eccentric Hungarian restaurant nestled in Greek Street, Soho, you are greeted with sumptuous dark furniture where the walls are adorned with frame after frame of caricatures and photographs, as well as random shelves of books. This fine place serves some true, homely Hungarian dishes - all typically stodgy, hearty and meaty. It is authentic with such things as strudel, goulash and galuska on the menu. Just reading what's they have on offer makes you feel so full!Where do I begin? For a starter you could have the Beef Goulash Soup (so filling it might as well be a main course) or Fish Dumplings in a creamy dill and mushroom sauce (again, very filling). I think it's just best to go straight to the main course and skip the starters as oh my are they rich. Go for the intensely substantial Chicken in a Creamy Paprika Sauce and Galuska (small dumplings). The light spicy twinge of the paprika is complimented by the smoothness of the heavy cream. Chicken is a good meat for this dish as any other  would almost be too much with such a creamy filled sauce, and don't forget the galuska which are little balls of stodge! If you still have space for it, you should try their walnut pancakes with chocolate sauce which goes down a treat.

JeCBS36u5v_AhTBIHYXS5A.text: I wanted to like GH but after trying the food I tend to agree with Laurel below.  The food was a bit bland.  The home-made goose pate was just OK and the creamed herring starter was good but a bit salty.  For the mains, the chicken in creamy paprika sauce & galuska was perfectly cooked, but bland in flavor.  The galuska was good (egg noodle).  The fish dumplings were the best out of all of the dishes but still just eh.  The Toptable 50% off food deal helped.

I-EOpPbqKlzyMddgzN1j_w.text: The gH has a lot of atmosphere (caricatures of pols), Hungarian food (lots of meat), and I wanted to like it.  But when one contrasts the sublime Suppenkuche in San Francisco, the history factor doesn't make up for food that is bland.   I had the veal goulash with galuska (dumplings), and mine was the best of the bunch.  It was hearty, but it was bland (as I said) and definitely was no Suppenkuche-like  jaegerschnitzel with spaetzle.  My grandmother used to cook vegetables to an inch of their lives, but she got with the times and freshened up, oh, a million years ago.  Similarly, I bet that in Hungary these days, they liven up traditional food with a bit of modern sensibility.  The Gay Hussar could easily do the same, keep all the ambiance, and bring the food a little into the present.  Then, this could be a winner.

VdOHH_es4wW7j_CrEd6Fog.text: As far as I'm aware, this is one of the two(!) London based Hungarian restaurants. It's famous for being a former(?) haunt of the political classes, and the caricatures that cover one wall downstairs remember some of the regulars. I'm not an expert, but I picked out Greg Dyke, the late Robin Cook, Norman Lamont (the eyebrows gave it away), Alastair Campbell (not a flattering picture), and various others. Apparently lots of unofficial deals and connivings have happened in the upstairs rooms in the past. Sadly we were seated downstairs, so missed out on any potential eavesdropping. I went because of my ever-increasing enthusiasm for things Hungarian, and the menu is a brilliant Magyar nostalgia-fest. From goulash soup (gulyásleves) cold sour-cherry soup (hideg meggyleves - better than it sounds), to paprika chicken (paprikás csirke), stuffed cabbage (töltött káposzta) and thick, paprika-laden stews (pörkölt), you can chow on down and pretend you're in Budapest. The only major difference is the fish - Carp, the fish of (Hobsons) choice in Hungary has been substituted with seabass and other far nicer fish requiring access to the seaside. The GH carries a selection of Hungarian wines, in addition to international choices. The red we had was good, and the wine list also includes an example of the delicious dessert wine from the Tokaji region - well worth splashing out on a glass to finish your meal. If you've never tried Hungarian food before, this is a good place to do it. Ok, ok, so it's possibly also one of only two places to do it in London, but regardless. The food's well prepared, and, though a little dear at full price they have been known to do discounts through restaurant-booking sites, so keep your eyes peeled.

5ISgQUV0bjC6DHnhaUjw6A.text: The reason I have been coming back time and again to the Gay Hussar over the years (30?) is the upstairs room(s). My favourite is the top floor, where there is a round table that can seat around 10. They don't make any charge for the room and it makes for an excellent, intimate occasion. Suitable for domestic or business occasions, the food is always reliable and good. Last tiem, I took along someone who spoke Hungarian, and the service was even better! One of my top two venues for a small gathering in London

Q7s2qK14ldH0iYXJIJiYsQ.text: One of the best places I've eaten in in London. Booked the upstairs room for a small group of friends and they all have said that the food was wonderful and the atmosphere was brilliant. I'd also really highly recommend the desert wine - Tokai - wow! Fantastic.

CD7zq8D5NLRQ3M1KZfEHQw.text: A very good soho institution, popular with politicians and journalists. Cosy and atmospheric, excellent service and good food. The food is traditional (and rather heavy) - if you want modern or even modern Hungarian you'll need to go elsewhere, but it is seriously good and well-priced.

KdM_9rCFACthaE5YQDJhFw.text: I didn't know what to expect from Gay Hussar when we came, but we arrived to discuss our book club book about Hungarian immigrants in the UK, so it seemed like an appropriate place to go. There doesn't seem to be a lot of seating, but there is an entire extra upstairs dining area where we were shown when we arrived.I opted to order a bottle of the Hungarian Cabernet Sauvignion, and I was pleasantly surprised on how good it was. I've had Tokaji in the past, so I know that was good, but I didn't know Hungarians could also do a decent job with regular wine as well.I ordered the mixed appetizers to start and the stuffed cabbage for a main. The appetizers were great, and it was nice having a selection of goodies to eat. I also tried the various soups, and the beef goulash soup was really great too. The cherry soup was flavorsome, but it was also really rich and sweet and the people who ordered it found it hard to finish. The stuffed cabbage was fantastic. I want the recipe. It was full of flavor and really well done. Several of us ordered it, and we were all happy. I also got an order of the poppyseed streudel for dessert, and everyone who tried it was really pleased.Gay Hussar makes some fantastic food, and I think I ordered well. I would definitely come back at another time to try some of the other wines and perhaps some of the other food as well. (Although that stuffed cabbage was so good, I might not.)

IqWS07CkPZt0YIHJaRl2ng.text: Traditional dishes home style in a very friendly restaurant. Real. No design no gourmet no foodaholic... simply a very good hungarian restaurant

naAIU3Zx284l1_nkHgimsQ.text: Overall the quality of the foods is average. I have been to Hungary and tried the local foods there before. So I could compare the hungarian dishes in london and hungary. Taste are quite similar. Some dish are good but other dish could be bad.  Veal Wiener Schnitzel with Saute Potatoes and Pepper Salad...the Potato is too dry and hard like dry potato chips. Veal Goulash with Galuska it come with rice, real good portion. Smoked Breast of Goose with Sólet and Red Cabbage...seem to be my favourite. Certainly the prices is not cheap. But if u really missed hungarian foods, may be you could try this as the location is right in the heart of soho...very close to Soho square.

photos.caption: Photo of Gay Hussar - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Gay Hussar - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Gay Hussar - London, United Kingdom

EgIzIkISMm7OL4xejLZluw.text: I knew that the gay hussar was an expensive tourist trap but I had an urge for goulash soup that could not be controlled. It was closer to a compulsion. I ordered the soup, which was watery with almost no meat and excessively spicy. Next came a Wiener schnitzel that was overcooked and excessively breaded. the breading was even falling off. It was amateur hour. Finally the cucumber salad: limp and flavorless. At least it was expensive.

wQx0Vmh-1rjp6WgQVCdKSA.text: This is an aggregate of 2 visits to the Gay Hussar. The first visit was with Andrew M's alpahbet dining gang - obviously, we were having H for Hungarian food that nightWe really enjoyed the roasted foie gras that night, judging it the best that we'd tasted in London. So, when we heard that the Gay Hussar was going to close recently, we made a reservation to have the foie gras again while we still couldThe Gay Hussar has been a fixture in Soho for many decades, being the favourite haunt of many famous politicians and writers as evidenced by photographs on the walls. The building does have an oldey worldey feel to it with creaky stairs and narrow passageways. On both visits, they put our group into the private dining room on the second floor for no extra costWe had our own waiter for the room. He was efficient if a little slow to warm up to real friendliness. We also had problems getting the bill on both visits - perhaps we don;t quite fit the demographic of their usual clienteleThe aforementioned seared foie gras was rich and nutty with caramelised edges, topped off with sweet caramelised onion. We all agreed that it tasted better the first time round for some reasonWe did try a lot of their dishes between us. I remember that the meat is better than the fish - the duck, goose and venuson were nice. The seafood dishes were less successfulThis classic London restaurant is worth a visit for the foie gras but stick to the meaty dishes

photos.caption: Photo of Gay Hussar - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Gay Hussar - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Gay Hussar - London, United Kingdom. Veal goulash

i2Vr9XWluTa06_44nUMDuA.text: A fantastic meal with friends.  I was craving a cabbage roll and was blessed with one of the best I've ever had.  Service was phenomenal.  Wine and dessert were delicious too.  Cozy, intimate seating ideal for dates or close friends.  Go!

QKdsAYPItJeUbks-c1F4cQ.text: Hmm. This place may be an institution, but the food is bland at best and unappealing at worst. We had some really odd dishes, like a fish terrine that contained both milk and gelatin. We had four dishes, and didn't like any of them very much. Service wasn't great, either.I would strongly recommend avoiding this place, unless you're going specifically because of its political history.

gSX7X3a54XFWK5pLkx9nDA.text: I love Hungarian food and have had it all over the world, including some of the best ever in Hungary.  It's increasingly difficult to find and there are only a handful left in the US. Growing up with a Hungarian grandmother next door who could cook lights out Hungarian I'm well versed in the cuisine and can pick things out of a non-English Hungarian restaurant menu with ease.  No need for that skill here since there are English translations of the dishes on the menu.First off, starting with some good Hungarian wine is a must and they have a very good selection. Hungarian wine is an underappreciated offering and is a far better bargain than a lot of others. It's not the Bulls Blood you see here in the States, oh no. It is spectacular wine of remarkable depth and character.  The appetizers must include of the cherry soup which is a delight. And the smoked Hungarian sausage is a good adder to get you started. I'm a huge fan of their Porkolt and the chicken Paprikash. Of course you can get the standard fare like goulash and schnitzel but you can get that anywhere. Go for something a little more out of your comfort zone - have you had smoked goose breast before? I'm betting you haven't. Try it.  Order another bottle of wine. Save room for the palacsinta with walnuts and chocolate sauce. Yum. I'm going back on my next trip to London for sure! Loved it!

UJfnydgTDFZOP5mdSpHc9A.text: This was my second time here...the first time was on a visit to my nephew who was over here for a couple of years, and took us here because he and his wife love it.  Last night we were back again...this time both of us were visiting his sister who's over here for 3 years. I was underwhelmed then and I was underwhelmed again.  It's not that the food is particular bad...but everything seems to be a variation on goulash...even the soup, which I swear in a blindfold test you would think it's chili, but good chili!  While they have a bar, when I tried to describe an old fashioned to the well meaning waiter...he translated it into a gin martini, so ok cheers.  The salami dish was good, there was a beet "pate" for lack of a description from The waiter that was exceptional...the salamis were good and my grandnephew loved what we think was a duck pate. As I mentioned I had the goulash soup for an entry and it was a very good Hungarian version of chili...right down to the meat.  As a side I had the cucumber salad which is sliced cukes , which must be marinated in something and then served with a yogurt sauce and was good.  Everyone else had goulash variations...beef, veal, and they all loved it, so it must just be my Hungarian food bias.

zlSGbbO4v17Onp-8JTwUow.text: Nice and comfy restaurant. Interesting menu and a good price quality ratio. The portion could've been a bit bigger and the soup of the day should change to something more interesting but overall a nice place.

photos.caption: Photo of Gay Hussar - London, United Kingdom. Goulash with Spatzle. All handmade and delicious. But the portion is quite small

V4psFOwQIZFCq5iXam3CPQ.text: Food was surprising bland. Csirkepaprikás needed a lot of salt but still lacked the signature onions and paprika flavors. Duck was overcooked and dry. Gulyásleves was average... All that for way too much money. If you want Hungarian in London, hop on a plane to Budapest, grab a meal and fly home... It may be cheaper.

Us98kkmXYAKdct7iMbhyCw.text: The Gay Hussar is a cute, cosy restaurant with great history and food- the caricatures of political figures on the wall are a talking point! The food is classic Eastern European winter warmer stuff, stews and pickled veg, we loved it. It'd be a nice place to take visiting relatives, very 'London' but not the normal touristy sort of thing. Good location too!

31OUU9EUKOjJ2NpcdEnk4g.text: I first visited the Gay Hussar in 2001. As someone of Hungarian ancestry, it's so hard to find a Hungarian restaurant anywhere, and I will always take advantage of it. In 2001, my parents and I all remembered the Gay Hussar being unbelievably good. My dad always said it was the best duck of his life. Fast forward to 2014 when I finally returned. Many trips to London in between had never found the Gay Hussar fitting in to my schedule, and I was excited to fit it in this trip, albeit for lunch this time.The space hasn't changed. I don't think it ever has. It's small, old, but comfortable. The lunch menu had 2 or 3-course meals for 21 and 25 pounds respectively, or you could order a la carte, which my wife and I did. First off, the food took FOREVER. Unacceptably long. The place really wasn't too busy, but it took at least an hour for it to come. Ridiculous, unacceptable. The service throughout was pretty mediocre - order, deliver, and pay are the only times the staff will even look at you. No "how is your food", no "more water?". Nothing. The food itself was mixed. My pork was okay. My wife's stuffed cabbage was really good. Portions were small for the price, and quality didn't seen to make up for it. Even for London, the prices were just too high. I miss the old G.H. I heard it was going on bad times and might close. It should. Pitiful excuse of a Hungarian restaurant, and bad representation of the fantastic country of Hungary.

8RP9I3V0P8Z3mehze85q4A.text: From the moment I stepped in I already felt I was warped back in time to the 1950s. Creaky floorboards, dark wooden paneling and a book shelf filled with old worn out political books. Wall covered with comical sketches of politicians. It did feel like a serious place to be. This was magnified by the fact it was dead silent when we walked in with only one other table taken and the rest of the place empty. We were early though and soon it got busy. For a place so empty in the beginning we did feel very awkward and exposed, craving for some light music in the background for some distraction. But it became understandable when other guests of journalists and suited people came in that this was no average romantic restaurant to dining. The place was small, narrow and confined- could be quite claustrophobic once it filled up. Till now I cannot decide if I liked the atmosphere or dislike as it was just awkward but interesting at the same time,Bread was already laid on the table with butter and next to that two red chillis for snacking- interesting, The butter and bread were forgettable and the chilli were mild but got spicy once you bit into the seeds. My boyfriend enjoyed those and described it like bell pepper on the outside, But food is what makes this place worthwhile. Our starter of a smoked Hungarian sausage was an excellent choice to get our tastebuds going, plump, juicy and peppery and went well with the gherkin and horseradish sauce that gave it that extra kick of flavour. However I did not taste any smokiness as much as I enjoyed it. Being pancake day we could not resist but order the chicken pancakes with spinach and rice as a main. It came in a very generous portion of two which probably matched up to it's high pricing. Personally I enjoyed this. It was hearty and comforting ,all soft textures, quite a filling heavy dish especially with the sour cream, the rice and the delicious tomato sauce it came in. The spinach was amazing, flavoursome and tasted fresh along with the fluffy rice that was lovely with the sauce and gave the dish a good bite.A more interesting dish and uniquely presented was the Smoked Goose breast which sat on a deep fried lattice fortress, filled with a bean stew under red cabbage with a dollop of cranberry sauce on the side. I wasn't too sure the flavours went well together with the cabbage being too sweet and watery for the bean stew and it definitely did not need a sugary coating from the cranberry sauce. But separately it can be admired for it's individual flavours. The goose was served pink, smokey and meaty- resembled a lot like roast pork. It was delicious. The beans were cooked well,  till tender, delicate flavours, another comfort delight with a nice crunch from the potato lattice. Personally I thought the red cabbage was cooked too long as it lost all it's texture. A slight bite to it would have improve this dish slightly. This dish was quite a mix bag together.We finished the meal with more pancakes and ordered both that was offered, Sweet Cheese Pancakes and Walnut Pancakes with chocolate Sauce. The Sweet Cheese Pancake definitely won me over. The perfect balance of sweet, soft creaminess and citrusy zing from the oranges was just a pure delight. And it was those soft textures coming together that made me prefer it over the walnut pancake. I didn't particularly enjoy the broken pieces of walnut inside of the pancake and it needed some sort of cream to bring the dish together. The chocolate sauce made it very heavy and rich but not sweet enough. It wasn't bad but wasn't great either.I did find Gay Hussar a very interesting meal. A lot of things that could be improved but I did find things I enjoyed a lot. Prices are very steep so a Tastecard offering 50% would be helpful or otherwise not really worth it. Service was slightly cold and a bit too formal by our male waiter but I think he was too used to serving politicians.Sadly the vibe just didn't suit us as nice as the food could be. Still it was a great insight to the political history of the place and I did not regret my visit.

photos.caption: Photo of Gay Hussar - London, United Kingdom. Gundel Palacsinta- Walnut Pancakes with Chocolate Sauce
Photo of Gay Hussar - London, United Kingdom. Old well maintained restaurant with a old looking bookshelf
Photo of Gay Hussar - London, United Kingdom. Chicken Pancakes with Rice and Spinach

BoWzmd7lOIo8k3QxVhHRDQ.text: Had a pre-theatre weeknight dinner here. Two tips: book a table ahead of time (it was so small and packed I was very glad we did) and give yourself plenty of time to enjoy it, because the service takes a long time. We gave ourselves about an hour and twenty minutes, but that flew by and suddenly we realized we still hadn't gotten our food 15 minutes before we needed to leave for the show! Another thing to note is that if you get a starter, they will wait for you to tell them you're ready to get the main dish - we didn't realize this until we'd been waiting a while.However, it was tasty food. Only one vegetarian option for the main dish, so naturally I went for the classic - veg goulash. We all split a Hungarian appetizer platter, and I picked out the few salad parts. I also enjoyed the red Bull's Blood Hungarian wine. I had never had Hungarian food, but I was happy with it and glad to try it. I just really wish we didn't have to down it so fast and could savor it longer. I also wish we would've had time to try a dessert, because they looked delicious!I came with friends/coworkers, and our group was two girls and a guy. Our server was Hungarian and quite a character - we got the impression that he assumed that my female friend and I were a couple! I guess mainly gays go to Gay Hussar. But it was funny, anyways. If you have plenty of time, I recommend checking it out!

gwj1HexRL1KNVi99DHtNKA.text: A unique restaurant that offers good hearty winter weather food. Make sure you sit upstairs to be in a more relaxed environment. The food itself was great and the service very helpful. Maybe it's due to its location in Soho but the prices are a bit steep but well worth a visit if you have a tastecard, 50% off. (Visit - 30/10/2014 Dinner)

b9BucAvcJCgST94V7-r5yQ.text: I would gladly go back here. The location is convenient, the food is really tasty, and the service is acceptable.The retaurant is small, so be sure to book reservations if you're going on a popular night. We ordered a variety of appetisers. The chilled cherry soup is really remarkable and unique. The fried mushrooms were a bit of a disappointment. Pretty much like you'd get from a pub's deep fryer. But the dill relish that came with them was unusual and interesting.I had the vegetarian goulash which had a bunch of delightful vegetables. My friends got the duck leg and the sea bass. Being a semi-pescatarian, I tried the sea bass and it was really something. I thoroughly enjoyed the vegetarian goulash and the fish. The potato cake that came with the fish was also very nice.I'm not thrilled with the service. It was not very attentive. But they were polite and we did get our food in a reasonable time. I definitely like the vegetarian choices here, and meat eaters can get good food they enjoy, too.

E3E3QMdNs5vk2hfm24MxMw.text: I had been dying to try Gay Hussar for the longest time with my dear Hungarian friend; but that never happened, because she moved back to Budapest. So when a friend from HK was visiting, I took her on her "I want to try something different" offer, and made a 7PM reservation for six people. I was somewhat surprised by the alacrity with which this reservation was made because i remember distinctly that a couple of times I did try making a reservation in the past, the response was "We've got something at 10PM, or at 6PM". OK - so, Gay Hussar - not so busy in the summer?? True to my conclusion, the ground floor had a few vacant tables even at 9PM.Hungary is a big wine producing nation. But you don't get to see that many Hungarian wines because they drink it all up before exporting any. We tried the Egri Blauburger 2008, simply because it said "light, smooth and easy". And easy it was. With 13% alcohol content, it went down like water. For the rest of the evening, the popular vote of the table was to continue with the same bottle.One of us got the Pácolt Hering which is a marinated fillet of Herring with soured cream. Beautifully laid out, it gushed a million flavours into my mouth. Good pick.I ordered the Veal Goulash with Galuska (hungarian for spätzle). The meat was fresh and the stew was fairly mild. So, yes, good quality food - but they could have been a little more generous with the quantity - after all it's just a stew, not caviar! My friend from HK got the Venison Goulash with Tarhonya (egg drop pasta) and red cabbage. This goulash was rich and red probably because of the wine. I could also taste the paprika afresh. Two of my co diners, one of whom got the schnitzel, and the other, the fish, said that their respective mains were "dry". I didn't taste portions from their plates, so I will not base my rating on their comments.Gay Hussar should showcase more paprika types on the table, both fresh and ground for diners to be able to sample this wondrous fruit which is almost synonymous with popular Hungarian culinary culture. There was one kind of chilli pepper on the table, but I was expecting more bell peppers, apple paprikas that I could savor with the meat.Desserts were good. The Gundel Palacsinta or Walnut Pancakes with Chocolate Sauce were like crepes with walnut crushed nutella. Delicious! The Dobos Torta - Layered Gateau with Caramel Top, was average - seemed like something you'd find in an average bakery. The Makos Retes (Poppy Seed Strudel with Vanilla Ice Cream) was definitely the best of the lot. I'd go back to Gay Hussar just for a bite of that bad boy.I would totally go back to Gay Hussar. I would say slightly overpriced on the mains, the wines/appetisers/desserts seem about right. So overall good value for money, friendly and prompt service and of course - fabulous location.

EAzUO_d9MHLfg4-A5ynUyQ.text: There doesn't seem to be much selection of Hungarian food in London despite the relatively large population. Usually that would mean the food here is good! There's enough people here who love that cuisine that some cook would make a proper home-style place. Guy Hussar had high potential in this regard. It does look like a great joint, the service was nice too. The food however is unlike anything I've ever had in Hungary. I imagine that this is the type of stuff they serve at a 2-star motel/diner! The menu had all the familiar choices with all the same home-style potential, but failed miserably. Maybe its just that this restaurant had the proper food originally but the English clientèle couldn't handle the spice and herbs, so they brought it down a few notches? Whatever the case, this food was bland. So bland in fact that I couldn't distinguish any one flavour or another, it was just like coloured tofu. My Hungarian girlfriend had the crispy goose which was equally (if not more) disappointing. Again, no flavour at all. Just ingredients that were cooked bare-bones without any kind of traditional seasoning. I could listen that there were other Hungarian patrons in the room as well, all with similar attitudes. Bottom line is this restaurant, or any ethnic restaurant, should NEVER cater to the English! Remember they aren't widely known for their centuries of culinary excellence (they colonized other countries for that). Instead restaurants should cater to themselves, to the food THEY want. I guarantee that Guy Hussar is not doing that now.

raPPP_SKJ0CDX3_PZv-uJQ.text: I went to this place on a whim based on a friend's recommendation, and found it to be an absolute gem. The service was wonderful - the waiter gave us half a bowl of the cherry soup to try before ordering, since none of us had had it before, and he talked us through the menu very clearly - and the food was mostly delicious.The one thing that didn't impress me were the chicken pancakes. Not sure if it just wasn't to my taste, or if it just wasn't what I was expecting, or what. But it was a bit saucy and didn't impress me as much as anyone else's mains. Everyone else's dish, by the way, was fantastic. It was my first experience with Hungarian food though, so I'm not sure how it compares to other Hungarian cooking.The cherry soup, by the way, is delicious - as was the poppy strudel we shared for dessert. We all definitely plan on returning.
